summary: Complete governance workflow for teams using and contributing to the GoA Design System, including decision criteria and communication channels
purpose: Guide teams through proper design system usage, problem-solving hierarchy, and contribution process

corePhilosophy.designSystemFirst: Start with existing components and patterns - covers ~80% of service needs
corePhilosophy.userDriven: Changes driven by usability testing and real user needs, not preferences
corePhilosophy.collaborative: Work with design system team for decisions and knowledge sharing
corePhilosophy.evidenceBased: Research and testing inform decisions, common sense applies for obvious issues

primary: Design System Support channel on Slack
communicationChannels.usage: Use any of these channels for questions, support, reporting issues, or discussing new needs

governanceWorkflow.description: Step-by-step process for teams working with the design system

step1.name: Use the Design System as Default
step1.description: Start with existing components and patterns to save time and build on current standards
step1.expectation: This should cover approximately 80% of your service needs
guidance: Use documented components and patterns first
Follow implementation examples and best practices
Don't create custom solutions before checking existing options
riskIndicators: Team building custom components that exist in design system
Spending significant time recreating existing functionality
Deviating from established patterns without user research

step2.name: Identify User Need Not Handled by Design System
step2.description: Through usability testing, discover when existing solutions don't meet user needs
triggers: Usability testing shows poor user experience
step2.beforeProceeding: Test current content and layout solutions before proposing component changes

step3.name: Talk to Design System Team
step3.description: Collaborate with design system team to understand options and make informed decisions
discussion_includes: What other teams have done for similar problems
What can be shared and reused across teams
step3.decision_authority: Product teams can do whatever they want, but design system team decides what becomes part of the shared system

step4.name: Apply Problem-Solving Hierarchy
step4.description: Recommended approach for addressing user experience issues

hierarchy.rationale: Often most impactful for user experience and easiest for developers to implement
Modify spacing, association, and relationships between elements
Create or modify interface components only after content and layout solutions have been explored

step4.philosophy: Start simple with content and information before applying UI solutions to design problems

step5.name: Test New Solution with Users
step5.description: Validate solutions through user feedback and testing
step5.approach: Testing and feedback from real users is always preferred
step5.timing: Ideally happening throughout the process - more user feedback is almost always better

step6.name: Share Learnings with Design System
step6.description: Communicate insights from design and development so other teams can benefit

outcomes.description: Solution meets contribution criteria and becomes part of shared design system
Solution stays unique to service but is tracked in design system backlog

step6.tracking: All solutions are tracked in the design system backlog regardless of outcome

contributionCriteria.description: Criteria used by design system team to determine if something becomes part of the shared system

useful.requirement: Evidence that component or pattern would be useful for many teams or services
evidence_types: Screenshots or links to usage in different services

unique.requirement: Does not replicate something already in the design system, OR provides evidence that it's better than existing version

better.requirement: Creates better experience for end user, informed by research showing UX improvement and response to user need

universal.requirement: Inclusive and accessible, meets or exceeds WCAG 2.1 accessibility standards

highRiskBehaviors.risk: Building Custom Components That Already Exist
highRiskBehaviors.description: Team spending significant design and development time recreating existing design system components
indicators: Custom button, input, or layout components
Significant time investment in solved problems
highRiskBehaviors.mitigation: Check design system first, use existing components, consult with design system team

highRiskBehaviors.description: Making component or design changes without user validation
highRiskBehaviors.mitigation: Conduct user research, test with real users, apply problem-solving hierarchy

highRiskBehaviors.description: Not engaging with design system team for guidance or knowledge sharing
indicators: No communication with design system team
highRiskBehaviors.mitigation: Use communication channels, participate in drop-in hours, share findings

highRiskBehaviors.description: Creating solutions that don't meet accessibility standards
highRiskBehaviors.mitigation: Follow WCAG 2.1+ standards, test with assistive technologies, consult accessibility experts

when_to_suggest_governance_process: Team asking about creating custom components
Questions about design system usage or gaps
Requests for component modifications or new patterns
User experience problems that might need design system solutions
process_guidance_approach: Encourage communication with design system team
Stress importance of user research and testing
Explain contribution criteria for shared solutions
risk_identification: Flag when teams might be recreating existing components
Identify missed opportunities for design system usage
Highlight when user research might be needed

successIndicators: Teams start with design system components as default
Regular communication with design system team
Learnings shared back to design system
Consistent user experiences across government services
